Kinetic - add kinetic to widget¶

Kinetic Scrolling widget for PyMT Initially written by Alex Teiche <xelapond@gmail.com>

class pymt.ui.widgets.kinetic.MTKineticScrollText(**kwargs)¶

Kinetic Scrolling widget It provides a vertical menu of items which you can scroll through by flicking your finger. --Similar-- to the one found on the iPhone.

Parameters:

‘bgcolor’ : The background color of the widget ‘icolor’ : The color for the items ‘iscolor’: The color for an item when it is selected ‘tcolor’ : Color for the text ‘font’ : Self explanitory ‘font_size’ : Self Explanitory ‘friction ‘ : The Psuedo-friction of the psuedo-

System Message: ERROR/3 (/usr/local/lib/python2.5/pymt/ui/widgets/kinetic.py:docstring of pymt.ui.widgets.kinetic.MTKineticScrollText, line 3)

Unexpected indentation.

kinetic scrolling. I like values of around 1.1

System Message: WARNING/2 (/usr/local/lib/python2.5/pymt/ui/widgets/kinetic.py:docstring of pymt.ui.widgets.kinetic.MTKineticScrollText, line 15)

Block quote ends without a blank line; unexpected unindent.

‘items’ : The plain-text items that you would like

to have within the widget.
Parameters inherited through mtwidget:
 

‘pos’ : Position ‘size’ : Size ‘color’ : Has no effect on this widget ‘visible’ : visibility

When an item is tapped and the blob has moved less than 10 pixels(so we know they aren’t scrolling) it fires a callback and passes the clicked text as the argument.

add(text)¶
Function adds a new element to the widget. If this object is tapped, then a callback is called with the text as the argument
draw()¶
dtext(text, pos, color=(0, 0, 0, 255))¶
Function to draw text at a given pos. The Label rendered is persisten throughout the life of this object for latency reasons. It is kept in self.label.
on_item_select(item)¶
Prototype for callback
on_touch_down(touches, touchID, x, y)¶
Callback for when a new touch appears. All we do here is set the friction to zero, so it stops as if we stopped it from spinning
on_touch_move(touches, touchID, x, y)¶
Callback for when a blob moves. Here we add the relative movement to the offset, to acheive the scrolling effect
on_touch_up(touches, touchID, x, y)¶
Callback for when the blob leaves the widget. Here we will set the last relative movement as the spin-down velocity, so it will continute to spin after we let go.
